funFacts: Persian became one of the first RTL (right-to-left) languages added to Google Translate in June 2009, only 6 months after its initial release.
Modern Persian adds four letters (پ چ ژ گ) to the Arabic script, which often confuses OCR engines trained only on Arabic.
Because many keyboards lack Persian layout, Iranians invented “Finglish” – writing Persian with Latin characters; large datasets of Finglish severely degrade machine translation accuracy.

Persian has kept a largely unchanged core vocabulary for over a millennium; classical poetry by Hafez or Rumi can still be understood by modern speakers, posing interesting challenges for translation memory systems.
In Unicode, Persian and Arabic share code points, but Persian numbers use different glyphs (۰۱۲۳۴۵۶۷۸۹), a common source of formatting bugs in translation software.
